sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Acute bacterial exacerbation of chronic bronchitis: 500 mg extended-release ORALLY every 12 hours for 7 days
  • Acute otitis media: 250 to 500 mg regular-release ORALLY every 8 to 12 hours
  • Bronchitis, acute - Secondary bacterial infection: 500 mg extended-release ORALLY every 12 hours for 7 days
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue: 375 mg extended-release ORALLY every 12 hours for 7 to 10 days; 250 to 500 mg regular-release ORALLY every 8 hours
  • Lower respiratory tract infection: 250 to 500 mg regular-release ORALLY every 8 hours
  • Pharyngitis: 375 mg extended-release ORALLY every 12 hours for 10 days; 250 to 500 mg regular-release ORALLY every 8 hours
  • Tonsillitis: 375 mg extended-release ORALLY every 12 hours for 10 days; 250 to 500 mg regular-release ORALLY every 8 hours
  • Urinary tract infectious disease: (regular-release) 250 to 500 mg ORALLY every 8 hours

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• Acute bacterial exacerbation of chronic bronchitis: (16 years or older) 500 mg extended-release ORALLY every 12 hours for 7 days
  • Acute otitis media: (1 month or older) 40 mg/kg/day regular-release ORALLY divided every 8 hours, MAX 1 g/day
  • Bronchitis, acute - Secondary bacterial infection: (16 years or older) 500 mg extended-release ORALLY every 12 hours for 7 days
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue: (1 month or older) 20 to 40 mg/kg/day regular-release ORALLY divided every 8 hours, MAX 1 g/day
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue: (16 years or older) 375 mg extended-release ORALLY every 12 hours for 7 to 10 days
  • Lower respiratory tract infection: 20 to 40 mg/kg/day regular-release ORALLY divided every 8 hours, MAX 1 g/day
  • Pharyngitis: (1 month or older) 20 to 40 mg/kg/day regular-release ORALLY divided every 8 to 12 hours, MAX 1 g/day
  • Pharyngitis: (16 years and older) 375 mg extended-release ORALLY every 12 hours for 10 days
  • Tonsillitis: (1 month or older) 20 to 40 mg/kg/day regular-release ORALLY divided every 8 to 12 hours, MAX 1 g/day
  • Tonsillitis: (16 years or older) 375 mg extended-release ORALLY every 12 hours for 10 days
  • Urinary tract infectious disease: (regular-release) 1 month or older, 20 to 40 mg/kg/day ORALLY in divided doses every 8 hours; MAX 1 g/day

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: renal impairment: caution with markedly impaired renal function; dose adjustment for moderate to severe renal impairment not usually recommended (plasma half-life 2.3 to 2.8 hours in patients with complete absence of renal function)

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Acute bacterial exacerbation of chronic bronchitis
  • Acute otitis media
  • Bronchitis, acute - Secondary bacterial infection
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue
  • Lower respiratory tract infection
  • Pharyngitis
  • Tonsillitis
  • Urinary tract infectious disease
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Gonorrhea
  • Sinusitis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity to antibiotics in the cephalosporin group

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• allergy, particularly to other drugs
  • Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea, including mild diarrhea to fatal colitis, has been reported; may occur 2 months or more after discontinuation; medical or surgical management and discontinuation may be necessary
  • hypersensitivity to penicillins; discontinuation required
  • gastrointestinal disease history, particularly colitis
  • renal impairment, markedly; monitoring recommended

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (1.4%)
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Stevens-Johnson syndrome, Toxic epidermal necrolysis
  • Gastrointestinal:Pseudomembranous enterocolitis
  • Hematologic:Hemolytic anemia
  • Other:Serum sickness due to drug (0.024% to 0.5%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Cefaclor is a bactericidal semisynthetic cephalosporin that inhibits cell wall synthesis. It is active against most strains of aerobic and anaerobic gram-positive and aerobic gram-negative bacteria.

0.title: Absorption
0.mono: Oral: Time to peak concentration, 30 min to 60 min

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Renal: approximately 60% to 85 % unchanged
  • Dialyzable: not established (hemodialysis); not established (peritoneal dialysis)

4.title: Elimination Half Life
4.mono:
• 0.6 h to 0.9 h
  • Reduced renal function: slightly prolonged

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • may be given with or without food
  • suspension, shake well before measuring the dose

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• fever
  • symptomatic improvement
  • CBC
  • hepatic/renal function
  • previous hypersensitivity to other beta-lactam antibiotics
  • signs of antibiotic-associated diarrhea
  • signs of serum-sickness-like reactions

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Generic
    • Oral Capsule: 250 MG, 500 MG
    • Oral Powder for Suspension: 125 MG/5 ML, 187 MG/5 ML, 250 MG/5 ML, 375 MG/5 ML
    • Oral Tablet, Extended Release: 500 MG
  • Ceclor
    Oral Powder for Suspension: 250 MG/5 ML
  • Ceclor Pulvules
    Oral Capsule: 250 MG, 500 MG

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
CEPHALOSPORINS
OVERDOSE: Acute ingestion of large doses of cephalosporins may result in nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. Seizures have developed after parenteral overdose. ADVERSE EFFECTS: COMMON: Hypersensitivity reactions, including anaphylaxis, may commonly occur with therapy; oral exposures are less likely to cause severe allergic reactions than parenteral exposures. Seizures have also been reported following therapeutic administration. Prolonged prothrombin times, thrombocytopenia, and coagulopathies associated with a qualitative platelet defect and aggregation abnormalities have been reported following IV cephalosporin therapy. Pseudocholelithiasis may follow intravenous administration of ceftriaxone. Several cases of fatal hemolytic reactions following intravenous ceftriaxone therapy have been reported in children with serious hematologic abnormalities.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
CEPHALOSPORINS
  • Decontamination: Generally not indicated in patients with no underlying health problems. Activated charcoal may be necessary for patients with underlying renal insufficiency.
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor renal function, electrolytes, CBC including platelets.
  • Anaphylaxis: Mild to moderate allergic reactions may be treated with antihistamines with or without inhaled beta adrenergic agonists, corticosteroids or epinephrine. Diphenhydramine: ADULTS: 50 mg orally, IV, or IM initially, then 25 to 50 mg orally every 4 to 6 hours for 24 to 72 hours. CHILDREN: 1.25 mg/kg orally, IV, or IM initially, then 5 mg/kg/day orally in 4 divided doses for 24 to 72 hours. Treatment of severe anaphylaxis also includes oxygen supplementation, aggressive airway management, epinephrine, ECG monitoring, and IV fluids.
  • Seizure: IV benzodiazepines, barbiturates
  • Blood coagulation disorder: Vitamin K, fresh frozen plasma
  • Intrathecal injection: Treat seizures with anticonvulsants (benzodiazepines, propofol, phenobarbital); endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation as needed. Keep the patient upright if possible. Immediately drain at least 20 mL CSF; drainage of up to 70 mL has been tolerated in adults. Follow with CSF exchange (remove serial 20 mL aliquots CSF and replace with equivalent volumes of warmed, preservative free normal saline or lactated ringers). For large overdoses, consult a neurosurgeon for placement of a ventricular catheter and begin ventriculolumbar perfusion (infuse warmed preservative free normal saline or lactated ringers through ventricular catheter, drain fluid from lumbar catheter; typical volumes 80 to 150 mL/hr). Dexamethasone 4 mg intravenously every 6 hours to prevent arachnoiditis.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
CEPHALOSPORINS
TOXICITY: Serious toxicity is unlikely following large oral doses of cephalosporins. Crystalluria and hematuria has been described in a 3-year-old boy who ingested 104 mg/kg of cephalexin. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: Varies with agent. CEPHALEXIN: CHILDREN: 25 to 100 milligrams/kilogram/24 hours orally, up to a maximum of 4 grams/day, divided every 6 hours.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause nausea, erythema multiforme (flu-like symptoms, spreading red rash, or with progression to skin/mucous membrane blistering), arthralgia, arthritis, or fever (more common in children).
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms serum-sickness-like reactions (rash, urticaria, arthralgia, fever, malaise, enlarged lymph nodes).
  • Advise patient to report severe diarrhea and consult healthcare professional prior to taking anti-diarrhea medicine. Other superinfection signs/symptoms should be reported as well.
